head.title: Ode I. To Melancholy.11 First published in Poetical Essays (1788), pp. 151-152; reprinted in New London Magazine [London] (November 1788), 603; and, later in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (April 12, 1796). Raymond Havens lists “To Melancholy” among the many poems influenced by Milton’s octosyllabic poems L’Allegro and Il Penseroso (1631). See Havens, The Influence of Milton on English Poetry, (New York: Russell & Russell, 1961, pp. 656 and 676); David Radcliffe reads it as a condensed version of John Milton’s Il Penseroso (ca. 1630), (Spencer and the Tradition).

lg.l: By the hills, or shady woods,
From isles the midnight spectres yell;
Or where some stalwart ruins nod,
Of wealth and grandeur once th’ abode,
Of ravens, and the screaming owl:
In all thy winning charms array’d;
Come, sober nymph, nor once disdain
To take me in thy pensive train.
